Project Description  The  Project  will  introduce  a  computerized,  double–entry,  cash 
basis public accounting system (PAS) with a central ledger. The 
Project will also reassign and consolidate responsibility for the 
overall government accounting function and for check issuance 
with the Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT). 
   
Rationale  Strengthening  of  the  PAS  will  enhance  good  governance  by 
improving efficiency, enhancing accountability and transparency, 
and contributing to more effective public sector management, as 
well  as  to  the  development  of  effective  fiscal  operations  and 
macroeconomic  policy.  The  quality  of  governance  in  public 
finance  management  is  critical  for  ensuring  expenditures  for 
programs targeting, reducing poverty, preventing corruption and 
fraud and reducing the vulnerability of the Maldives to external 
shocks. 
   
Objectives   The objectives are to (i) promote improved budget practices, thus 
enhancing financial management as well as the development of 
effective  fiscal  operations  and  macroeconomic  policymaking; 
(ii) establish accurate, reliable, and timely financial reporting to 
meet international accounting standards by eliminating laborious 
manual financial reporting systems, promoting accountability, and 
providing appropriate financial information to the Government for 
economic decision making; and (iii) conduct more comprehensive 
and updated control over public funds, and help develop a cash 
management  strategy  to  rationalize  cash  movements  and 
holdings, especially for the atolls and islands. 
 
The Project components include (i) restructuring the organization 
of ministries and departments (by establishing finance sections in 
ministries,  assigning  accounting  and  internal  audit  function  to 
MOFT,  and  establishing  accounting  units  in  the  atolls  and 
islands);  (ii)  strengthening  the  PAS  by  introducing  core 
government funds; chart of accounts; a ledger structure; and a 
voucher system for ministries, atolls, and islands; and preparing 
annual financial statements; (iii) streamlining the function of the 
Maldives Monetary Authority (MMA) for the PAS by reassigning 
the banking function to MMA, and establishing one public account; 
and (iv) supporting human resource development and training.

Project Benefits and  Introducing the new PAS will entail the following main benefits: 
Beneficiaries   (i) improving the quality, timeliness, and integrity of the accounting 
system will enhance transparency and accountability, and thus 
strengthen governance; (ii) reliable and timely information on the 
financial position of the Government will enable the Government 
to  conduct  more  competent  fiscal  policy  and  macroeconomic 
management to reduce the vulnerability to external shocks due to 
the high dependency of the Maldivian economy on imports and 
limited  income  derived  from  tourism  and  fishing;  (iii) reliable 
information on the fiscal status of the country will enhance lenders 
and investor confidence in the country; (iv) external reports will be 
prepared to meet internationally accepted accounting standards to 
enable better assessment by international rating agencies; and 
(v) significant reductions in idle cash holdings of ministries and 
atolls will lead to better financial returns on public funds through 
improvements in fiscal discipline and cash management.

I.   THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of the Maldives for the Strengthening of the Public Accounting System Project.  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  High dependence of the Maldivian economy on imports, and limited income derived from 
tourism and fishing exacerbates its vulnerability to external shocks. The effects of external 
shocks are quickly transmitted to the poor.  Hence, despite the significant economic and social 
progress  achieved,  the  incidence  of  poverty  is  still  substantial,  particularly  in  the  highly 
dispersed, small, and sparsely populated islands. This poses major structural challenges for the 
country as articulated in the Government’s Sixth National Development Plan (2001–2005). The 
Government's public expenditures account for more than 40% of the gross domestic product. 
Thus, public sector intervention is a powerful tool for economic and social development. 
 
3.  The Government's growth and poverty reduction strategy focuses on strengthening the 
macroeconomic  framework  and  good  governance  in  the  public  sector,  supporting  human 
development,  and  improving  the  policy  environment  for  the  public  and  private  sectors. 
Establishing  a  modern  public  administration  system,  governed  by  a  comprehensive  and 
transparent  set  of  laws,  and  an  impartial  and  competent  judiciary  is  prioritized  in  the 
Government’s development agenda, while efficient control and utilization of public money is 
underscored as a means to attaining the maximum benefits from the development program. 
4.  The  operational  strategy  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for  the  Maldives 
supports poverty reduction through a combination of pro-poor growth, social development, and 
good  governance  initiatives.  For  pro-poor  growth,  ADB’s  assistance  is  fostering  regional 
development.  To  raise  the  level  of  social  development,  ADB’s  focus  is  on  assisting 
postsecondary education and skills development. To support good governance, ADB is focusing 
on developing improved information access and public sector connectivity, and improving the 
effectiveness of public sector management. Introduction of a new public accounting system 
(PAS) will enhance good governance by improving efficiency and control of public money, 
enhancing accountability and transparency, and contributing more effectively to public sector 
management as well as the development of effective fiscal operations and macroeconomic 
policy.  Once  funds  that  are  dispersed  throughout  the  system  are  clearly  identified  and 
consolidated,  they  could  then  be  utilized  for  programs  targeting  poverty  reduction  and 
preventing  corruption  and  fraud,1 which  mostly  affect  the  poor.  Moreover,  the  quality  of 
governance  in  public  finance  management  is  critical  in  reducing  the  vulnerabilities  of  the 
Maldives to external shocks. 
      
5.  Since 1994, the Government has been collaborating with aid agencies to develop a 
more  efficient  public  finance  system.  More  recently,  the  public  expenditure  and  public 
accounting systems were enunciated as issues for immediate attention in the Sixth National 
Development Plan. Under a World Bank initiative, ADB and the International Monetary Fund

6.  The public accounting and auditing system needs to be streamlined to enable public 
money to be managed in an efficient and accountable manner. ADB has been working with the 
Government for the past 5 years as its lead partner in achieving this goal. ADB provided 
technical assistance (TA)2 to the Government from August 1997 to December 1998 to conduct 
an assessment of the existing PAS and to identify its major limitations, inadequacies, and 
weaknesses. This was followed by TA3 to identify the legal, institutional, and human resource 
requirements for introducing a new PAS.  
 
7.  In April 2001, after reviewing the findings and recommendations of these studies, the 
Government decided to adopt the design and the supporting reform strategies for introducing 
the new PAS.4  During the Country Strategy and Program Mission in May 2001, the Government 
asked ADB to provide a project preparatory TA5 for the proposed Project. The TA vetted the 
details of how a new PAS could interface with and update the existing accounting system with 
as little disruption to the economy as possible, through a critical review of proposed PAS 
models, system requirements, and capabilities in the Maldives. The findings of the TA team 
were then discussed in detail with the Technical Advisory Team and the Ministerial Level 
Advisory Group. The feedback received was included in the final TA report. Building on the TA 
recommendations and findings, a fact-finding mission6 was undertaken from 7 to 18 April 2002 
for the Project. This report is based on the understandings reached with the Government during 
fact-finding. The project framework is detailed in Appendix 1. 
 
A.  Performance Indicators, and Analysis 
8.  The  current  PAS  is  rudimentary  and  does  not  achieve  the  overall  objectives  and 
consistent performance criteria required for PAS. These objectives and criteria include provision 
of accurate and adequate information in a timely manner on the financial position, budgetary 
commitments and operation results of the funds (surplus or deficit positions) monitored by the 
accounting groups of ministries and atolls,7 in accordance with generally accepted accounting 
principles; compliance with finance-related constitutional, statutory, and legal requirements and 
contractual provisions of the country; and streamlined financial reporting to enable budgetary 
and accounting functions to be complementary and to effectively integrate elements of financial 
management and audits.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Capacity Constraints 
 
9.  Public sector staff involved with the accounting function work at a relatively rudimentary 
level in line with the requirements of a manual, line-budget oriented accounting system. To 
ensure adequate implementation of the new PAS, the skills mix will have to be substantially 
upgraded  not  only  to  implement  the  new  accounting  practices,  but  also  for  financial 
management, preparation and analyses of financial statements, and their use as inputs into 
macroeconomic policymaking. Other external funding agencies have not assisted in this area as 
the absorptive capacity of the Government is limited. While the Project will provide focused 
capacity building in phases to the relevant staff vis-à-vis workshops and on-the-job training, the 
pace of the process will largely be determined by the existing and absorptive capacity of the 
staff being trained. 
 
10.  A new PAS would not have been effective without the necessary legal foundation. 
Hence, under the capacity-building TA (footnote 3), three key bills for the public finance act, the 
amendments of the Audit Act, and the public enterprise act were drafted and are being reviewed 
by the Maldivian legislative authorities for adoption. The bills aim to define the legal framework 
within which the transparent and efficient implementation of the new PAS can be enforced, 
ultimately ascertaining an alignment of the newly introduced rules with practices. Many of the 
concepts, some of the terminology included in the bills are novel. Hence, a training workshop on 
these new bills, in conjunction with the Public Service Division of the President's Office, as part 
of  the  Seminar  on  Financial  Management,  was  held  in  June  2002,  for  a  group  of  senior 
government officials and financial managers of public sector organizations.  
 
2.  Scope for Improvement of the Existing Public Accounting System   
 
11.  The existing PAS, which was introduced more than three decades ago, is subject to a 
number of constraints. The financial legislative framework is not comprehensive. Currently, the 
country has an outline legal framework for regulating control of public finances including the 
PAS. The framework components are the Constitution of the Republic of the Maldives 1997,8 
and in operational terms, the Financial Regulations.9 Under the current PAS, no annual financial 
statements  regarding  the  Government’s  financial  position  and  status  are  reported  to  the 
People’s Majlis,10 and no audited financial statements are prepared. The annual accounts and 
information  on  Government  finances  are  presently  included  in  budget  papers11 and  the 
Government Budget in Statistics Handbook.12 In fact, no policies identify the ownership and 
responsibility for the accounting function, and provide for a data entry system. Only a limited

3.  Life of the Project  
 
12.  The Project is to be implemented over 3 years. While this may appear to be a relatively 
tight schedule, the pace of implementation is important. The Maldivian economy urgently needs 
a new PAS. Support for the Project is strong throughout the Government, and the momentum 
must  not  be  lost  during  implementation.  The  dependence  on  information  technology  and 
computers, while facilitating a less labor-intensive and more user-friendly introduction to the 
system, necessitates a reasonable pace of transition from the existing to the new PAS. The 
specialized accounting software and hardware to be used must still be at par with the rest of the 
world by the time the new PAS is operational. Designed carefully over the last 2 years in close 
consultation with the Government, the current timetable is realistically achievable from both 
technical and absorptive capacity perspectives at this time. However, the Project will be closely 
monitored by ADB and the Government; three monitoring missions and two comprehensive 
reviews  of  the  Project  are  scheduled.  If  during  implementation,  a  longer  implementation 
schedule appears to be needed, then both ADB and the Government will explore the availability 
of additional funding or TA from ADB and other donors. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT  
A.  Objectives 
13.  The ultimate goal of the Project is to improve the quality of governance by introducing a 
new PAS with institutional reorganization and capacity building aiming to enhance efficiency, 
accountability,  and  transparency;  and  contributing  more  effectively  to  public  sector 
management; as well as the development of effective fiscal operations and macroeconomic 
policy.  
 
14.  The objectives are to (i) promote improved budget practices, thus enhancing financial 
management as well as the development of effective fiscal operations and macroeconomic 
policymaking; (ii) establish accurate, reliable, and timely financial reporting to meet international 
accounting standards by eliminating laborious manual financial reporting systems, promoting 
accountability, and providing appropriate financial information to the Government for economic 
decision making; and (iii) conduct more comprehensive and updated control over public funds 
and help develop a cash management strategy to rationalize cash movements and holdings, 
especially  at  the  atolls  and  islands.  The  Project  covers  nation-wide  Government  agencies 
involved in the PAS in Maldives including ministries, atoll offices, island offices14 and will provide 
the financial reporting framework for public enterprises.

B.  Components and Outputs 
15.  The  features  of  the  proposed  PAS  are  summarized  in  Appendix  2.15 The  project 
components  include  (i)  the  restructuring  organization  of  ministries  and  departments  by 
establishing finance sections in ministries, assigning accounting and internal audit function to 
MOFT, and establishing accounting units in the atolls and islands; (ii) strengthening the PAS by 
introducing core government funds; chart of accounts; a ledger structure; and a voucher system 
for ministries, atolls and islands; and preparing annual financial statements; (iii) streamlining the 
function of the Maldives Monetary Authority (MMA) in the PAS by reassigning banking function 
to MMA, and establishing one public account; and (iv) supporting human resource development 
and training.  
  
1.  Organizational Restructuring of Ministries and Departments  
 
a.  Establishment of Finance Sections in Ministries 
 
16.  Presently 176 spending units are submitting budgets to MOFT. By introducing the new 
PAS, each ministry will be able to consolidate its own budget for presentation to MOFT as well 
as consolidate its accounting function by establishing a finance section. It will also enhance the 
efficiency and effectiveness of the overall administration of each ministry.  
 
17.  Under this component, a finance section in charge of the accounting and budgeting 
functions will be established under the relevant administrative division of each ministry. The 
administrative division of each ministry will comprise sections dealing with finance, human 
resources,  and  other  supporting  services.  The  finance  section  will  be  responsible  for  the 
accounting  functions  within  the  ministry,  which  includes  purchasing,  accounts  receivable, 
accounts payable, and reporting and budgeting, and will consolidate the ministry’s budget for 
submission to MOFT.     
 
    b.  Transfer of the Accounting Function from MMA to MOFT, and   
      Strengthening of MOFT’s Audit Functions 
 
18.  This  component  will  support  reorganization  of  MOFT,  to  provide  an  adequate 
organization structure for transferring the accounting function from MMA to MOFT and for 
developing an internal audit function. This component will also establish the treasury division 
and internal audit bureau. 
 
19.  The treasury division will consist of an accounting office, a cash management and fund 
release office, and a borrowing and debt management office. The accounting office will examine 
and certify vouchers, handle data entry operations, process general ledger and journals entries, 
handle  check  production,  and  maintain  computer  software  and  hardware.  Accordingly,  the 
accounting office will include an examination section, a data input section, a general ledger 
processing section, a check production section, a cashier’s section, and a computer section. 
The accounting office will require 25 to 30 staff.

20.  Internal auditing provides an independent, objective assurance and consulting capacity 
designed to add value and improve an organization’s operations. The internal audit bureau will 
review, appraise, approve and report on the adequacy and effectiveness of internal controls and 
financial performance and resource utilization under MOFT. It will report to the Minister of State 
for Finance and Treasury, as well as to each ministry and department it audits. These reports 
will be available to the Maldives Audit Office and the President’s Office. About 20 to 25 staff will 
be needed.  
   
21.  By establishing the internal audit bureau in MOFT, the Maldives Audit Office will take 
over the role of a supreme audit institution. It will be responsible for certifying the annual 
financial statements of the Government, and be the Government’s external auditor, reporting to 
the People’s Majlis through the President’s Office.   
 
c.  Establishment of Accounting Units 
 
22.  This component will help establish atoll and island accounting units.   
 
      i.  Atoll Accounting Units 
 
23.  The atoll accounting units will take over the functions currently performed by individual 
atoll entities, and create imprest accounts to provide cash funds for expenditures and to receive 
revenue collection. This will centralize the expenditure and revenue function in one unit on each 
atoll, compared with the existing decentralized management of revenue and expenditure. This 
organizational and functional change will strengthen financial control, and reduce the cash 
holdings and the physical movement of cash. In addition, a voucher system will be introduced to 
replace the existing system of manually prepared books. 
 
      ii.  Island Accounting Units 
 
24.  The island accounting units will take over the functions currently performed by individual 
island entities located away from the atoll offices and create a subimprest account for each 
island (from the atoll imprest account) and introduce a voucher system to replace the existing 
system.  
 
  2.  Strengthening of the PAS 
 
  a.  Basis of Accounting and Operational Mode of the PAS 
 
25.  The basic design and operational mode of the Project is to develop a computerized, 
double-entry, cash-basis PAS with a central ledger and check production unit under the control 
of MOFT.  
 
26.  The current system focuses on the control of public money using a manual accounting 
system operated using 9 accounting books. By introducing a computerized PAS, reliable and 
timely reporting of the financial status based on accurate transaction recording will be enabled. 
The existing single-entry system does not produce adequate financial information for overall 
reporting purposes. Double entry is the basis for producing standardized financial statements 
with  accuracy  and  reliability.  Accountability  and  transparency  of  financial  recording  and 
reporting will thus be enhanced. A cash-basis accounting system will provide all the necessary 
financial information for external reporting of government financial transactions. Furthermore, 
such a system, which is less complex than an accrual accounting system and requires less

7
extensive accounting skills, is also more consistent with the current Government capacity. The 
centralized accounting system, which is generally associated with a cash-basis system, will 
typically provide for one main financial report to be prepared. Under the proposed centralized 
system, MOFT will maintain the general ledger. MOFT will be responsible for the accounting 
processes as well as check production for the Government.   
 
  b.  Core Government Funds  
 
27.  This component will establish four core Government funds, which will group the public 
funds for financial information processing.  The core funds will be the consolidated revenue 
fund, loan and capital works fund, advance fund, and trust fund; all will be linked to a single 
bank account at MMA.16  
 
28.  This framework ensures compliance with two accounting principles: (i) expenses of an 
ongoing nature are resourced from taxation and other recurrent revenue sources, while capital 
works (and therefore assets) are funded from a loan fund or recurrent revenues set aside for the 
purpose;  and  (ii)  financial  information  is  clear  and  more  transparent  to  improve  the 
Government’s financial management.  
 
    c.  Chart of Accounts and Proposed Ledger Structure 
 
29.  The chart of accounts and structure of the ledger determine the manner in which data is 
classified, sorted, and aggregated for financial reporting.  A structure of hierarchical reporting 
levels  is  proposed  in  this  component,  which  will  accommodate  the  existing  reporting 
requirements, and allow expansion to accommodate future requirements as they arise.

C.  Special Features 
45.  The Project includes several important features that are being introduced or enhanced 
under the new PAS.  
 
1.  Cash Management 
 
46.  A  single  public  bank  account  and  centralized  accounting  system  offers  significant 
advantages over the present system of multiple accounts. It will provide a large, central pool of 
cash that can be managed and invested in a range of short- and long-term investments. This 
project  component  will  support  the  development  of  investment  strategies  where  a  mix  of 
investments will be undertaken to ensure that sufficient cash is available to meet requirements, 
while keeping the reserve of idle and uninvested cash to a minimum.   
 
47.  Investments are to be structured to provide short-term liquidity, and maintain a positive 
daily account balance with a sufficient safety margin. Daily investment decisions (whether to

2.  Computerization and Information Technology  
 
48.  The  proposed  PAS  can  only  be  properly  maintained  with  sufficient  backup  from 
customized  computerization  of  the  process.  This  project  component  will  support  such 
computerization. At present, only 10 personal computers (PCs) are available for budgeting and 
accounting activities in MOFT; they are either standalone or exist in small local peer-to-peer 
networked groups. All data are kept and reports generated using spreadsheets. Apart from a 
single pension database, no database management systems currently exist. Although usage is 
mostly rudimentary, all government agencies utilize computers. Moreover, a plan to network 
MOFT into a Windows-based networking environment is already under way. Under this plan, to 
be completed in 2002, a local area network with basic networking facilities such as file sharing 
and E-mail with a dedicated connection to the Internet is envisaged. The plan also includes the 
procurement of 32 additional PCs within 3 years for MOFT, of which 10 will be allocated to the 
accounts department, in tandem with the phased implementation schedule of the new PAS.24  
 
49.  The computerized PAS will incorporate all the functionality of the central accounting 
system  proposed  for  the  Government.  The  system  will  be  capable  of  fully  supporting  the 
centralized double-entry system of the PAS, adopting a phased approach to computerize the full 
system.  
 
50.  The implementation of the computerized PAS will take place in three phases. In the first 
phase, only MOFT will have direct access to the computerized accounting system, while the 
other ministries, atolls, and islands will prepare the vouchers based on the ledger structure and 
chart of accounts, and provide them to MOFT. All data entry will take place in MOFT, with hard 
or soft copies of reports needed by other government agencies sent manually or via E-mail. The 
second phase will allow access to the computerized PAS by other ministries and agencies, but 
access will be restricted to on line viewing of their account details. Web servers and dial-up 
servers should be in place before the initiation of this phase. On line data entry by other 
agencies into the computerized PAS will commence in phase three. Agencies will be able to log 
in to the system and update their records. The timing of each phase will be determined based 
on the pace of training (on accounting, financial management, etc.) necessary for the relevant 
personnel to implement the system and the ease with which the new PAS can replace the 
existing methodology. 
 
51.  The accounting software package will be customized by the vendor to address the 
existing needs and modalities of the Maldivian economy, data entry, and generation of various 
forms in Thaana (local script) as well as English. Thaana is right-to-left oriented as opposed to 
the western method of left-to-right data entry.

52.  The computerized accounting system will adopt the following operational principles. It

management servers, etc. should be in place. Firewalls and intrusion detection software have to 
be in place and under 24-hour surveillance, and any intrusion attempts attended to, where 
possible recorded and appropriate legal actions taken. For the long-term integrity of the system, 
local information technology (IT) experts, who could maintain and safeguard the system, will be 
trained  during  implementation,  overseen  by  international  IT  consultants.  The  step-by-step

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Project Benefits and Beneficiaries 
72.  The main benefit of the new PAS will be improved governance. The new PAS will 
establish a system of tracking receipts and expenditures of all public transactions at the central, 
atoll, and island level. Detailed financial/accounting data will then be used to generate financial 
statements to guide public sector management in the short and medium term, as well as 
macroeconomic planning in the longer term. Ultimately, the new PAS will improve efficiency, 
and enhance accountability and transparency, by achieving the overall objectives and meeting 
the performance criteria required of a well-functioning, up-to-date PAS. The beneficiaries of 
these improvements will all be citizens who will benefit from more efficient management of the 
nation’s resources. The quality of governance in public finance management is critical for 
poverty  reduction,  which  facilitates  participatory,  pro-poor  policies  as  well  as  sound 
macroeconomic management. Upgrading governance by introducing the new PAS will ensure 
the transparent use of public funds, promote effective delivery of public services, and provide 
good public expenditure management necessary for fiscal discipline, economic growth, and 
equity.

17
73.  The Project will also entail the following main benefits relevant to good governance: 
(i) reliable and timely information on the financial position of the Government will enable the 
Government  to  conduct  more  competent  fiscal  policy  and  macroeconomic  management  to 
reduce the vulnerability to external shocks, (ii) reliable information on the fiscal status of the 
country will enhance the confidence of lenders and investors in the country, (iii) the preparations 
of external reports to meet internationally accepted accounting standards will enable better 
assessment  of  the  economic  situation  by  international  rating  agencies,  and  (iv)  significant 
reductions in idle cash holdings of ministries and atolls will lead to better financial returns on 
public funds through improvements in fiscal discipline and cash management.  
 
B.  Economic Analysis   
74.  A  benefit-cost  analysis  was  conducted  for  the  Project  (Appendix  9).  The  economic 
internal rate of return is not computed since the majority of the benefits accruing from the 
Project are not quantifiable. A benefit that will have a significant fiscal impact is better financial 
returns on public funds through improvements in fiscal discipline and cash management. The 
existence of idle cash will be minimized if not totally eliminated. Excess funds can be properly 
channeled to more effective investment. Gains will also be made in efficiency and savings in 
staff time, which are a direct result of reducing the time of handling more than 1,600 bank 
accounts in favor of a single public bank account. Substantial time saving can also be achieved 
when the existing detailed record-keeping system is replaced by a simplified and cost-effective 
fully publicized system. Internal control procedures will also be improved. This will directly result 
in the reduction of misappropriation and overspending of government funds. Accountability for 
public funds will increase, resulting in informed spending. 
 
75.  In  addition  to  the  gains  from  better  financial  management  of  Government  funds, 
substantial  benefits  are  expected  to  accrue  from  improved  governance,  transparency,  and 
accountability of the public sector. Another benefit is the enhanced quality of external reports 
that  would  meet  internationally  accepted  accounting  standards.  The  ability  to  prepare 
independently  audited  government  financial  statements  will  lead  to  improvements  in 
international credit ratings and help the country to borrow funds in international markets at more 
favorable terms in the long run.  
   
76.  The Project is expected to pave the way for the new PAS to be connected to the national 
network enabling on line inquiry and printing of various financial reports of the government 
spending  units.  This  connectivity  will  bring  improvements  to  the  timeliness  and  quality  of 
decision making. The availability of reliable and timely information in a centralized system will 
result  in  more  informed  and  efficient  allocation  of  resources.  In  more  general  terms,  the 
proposed PAS will improve the entire financial management process.  
   
77.  The costs that will be incurred during project implementation will include: (i) consulting 
and computer software and hardware (ii) additional staff requirements especially in the initial 
stages  of  project  implementation,  such  as  staff  for  data  entry  in  MOFT  during  phase  1; 
(iii) system maintenance, and (iv) retraining employees.  
 
C.   Social Impact 
78.  The enhanced legislative framework associated with the new PAS and the targeted 
sound  public  finance  management  will  contribute  to  the  Government's  ongoing  efforts  to 
improve transparency, accountability, efficiency, and accuracy of public sector management. 
The new PAS will also enhance the Government’s ability to budget for, invest in, and monitor

1  8   
effectively economic and social development activities. These factors would in due course 
support more robust economic growth, thereby contributing to poverty reduction. The major part 
of the Project is assistance to strengthen the PAS in the Government. No infrastructure is to be 
built. Only computer equipment and software are to be purchased. The Project will not trigger 
ADB’s policies for involuntary resettlement or indigenous peoples. 
 
79.  In  line  with  ADB’s  initial  poverty  and  social  analysis  criteria,  participation  of  all 
stakeholders,  labor  issues,  gender  issues,  and  potential  risks  and  vulnerabilities  were 
considered in assessing the possible social and poverty impact of the Project on the Maldivian 
economy. The Government’s commitment at various levels is strong and stakeholders (i.e. 
government  ministries,  departments,  and  institutions)  endorse  the  introduction  of  a  more 
streamlined PAS. Key stakeholders such as the Audit Office, MMA, and MOFT especially 
expressed their strong support for the new PAS to the Mission. However, more awareness 
needs to be built of the structure and expected benefits of the new PAS, as well as how it is 
expected  to  interface  with  the  existing  accounting  system  during  the  early  stages  of 
implementation. 
 
80.  Sound  planning  and  delivery  of  training  on  the  PAS  is  essential  for  its  successful 
implementation. The training opportunities within the new PAS will have an overall positive 
social impact, through capacity building of the labor force involved. Training will not only be 
delivered in the initial stages of implementation, but thereafter as well, so that there is a 
continuous  supply  of  competent  staff  for  the  government  is  ensured  with  the  required 
management, budgeting, accounting and computer skills.  
 
81.  The Maldives has a progressive policy on gender in which achieving gender equality and 
equity are national objectives. Preliminary analysis indicates that women constitute 61% of 
government  staff  involved  in  administering  and  monitoring  public  expenditures.  Moreover, 
women’s labor force participation is projected to improve significantly since the country has 
achieved gender parity in primary and secondary educational participation maintaining gender 
equity in the intensive training for the PAS will necessitate that women receive due access to 
training and other opportunities of the Project.  
 
D.  Risks 
82.  First, a significant potential risk is the delay in enactment of the public finance act, 
amendment to the Audit Act, and the public enterprise act, and in issuing the relevant public 
finance instructions. The preparation for draft acts and instructions in English and Dhivehi have 
been under way by extending work of consultants under the capacity-building TA (footnote 3). 
The drafts are expected to be completed by the third quarter of 2002, with submission to the 
People’s Majlis expected in the fourth quarter of 2002 or early 2003. The Government assures 
that MOFT will have prepared these drafts and instructions and will have submitted them to the 
Law Commission for approval and the Law Commission will have submitted the drafts (as 
finalized by the Law Commission) to the People’s Majlis before loan effectiveness. 
 
83.  Second, relating to the project management, another risk is decision making by the PSC. 
The  PMU  will  prepare  necessary  draft  plans  (17  plans  as  described  in  para.  57)  and 
documentation to assist the PSC in making timely decisions or recommendations for the higher 
authority of the Government for approval, if necessary. The background reasons for delayed 
decision making are considered to include: (i) less frequent opportunities for decision-making 
meetings,  (ii)  lack  of  project  administration  capacity  in  preparing  for  those  meetings,  and 
(iii) unwillingness to change and uncertainty about introducing a new system. If the decision

19
making  is  not  conducted  in  a  timely  manner,  it  may  cause  a  significant  delay  for  project 
implementation. 
 
84.  Third, capacity building for relevant supporting staff in MOFT, ministries, atolls, and 
islands  is  critical  for  successful  project  implementation,  which  will  put  the  procedures  into 
practice under the new organization structure as well as enhance the aptitude of officers to 
interpret and take appropriate actions based on the outputs of the system. The Project will 
initially begin the training needs assessment in the second quarter following commencement of 
implementation;  it  will  examine  the  human  resource  needs  of  both  primary  and  support 
personnel, and training activities in the short term to implement the new PAS as well as in 
medium term to create new institutional structures to ensure sustainability. The initial phase of 
human resource development and training components will last until the fourth quarter before 
starting the first phase of the Project when MOFT will have direct access to the computerized 
accounting system. Successful capacity building during the first half of the implementation 
period is essential.  
 
V.   ASSURANCES  
A.  Specific Assurances 
85.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents. 
 
86.  The Government will: 
 
(i)  ensure the establishment of the treasury division within 6 months after loan 
effectiveness; 
(ii)  ensure the remaining MOFT positions agreed with ADB, are filled as per Human 
Resource Gap Study dated July 2002 (footnote 5) within 6 months after loan 
effectiveness; 
(iii)  provide the PMU with adequate budgetary and staff resources for its effective 
operation during project implementation in suitable office accommodation; 
(iv)  allocate  appropriate  budgetary  resources  to  concerned  ministries  for 
transportation  and  lodging  for  participants  attending  training  sessions  and 
workshops related to the Project; 
(v)  provide the required counterpart funds in a timely manner for the Project during 
implementation; and ensure all necessary authorizations, including presidential 
orders, are granted and approvals are given to ensure timely implementation of 
the Project; 
(vi)  ensure  the  installation  of  the  project-related  computer  facilities  with  relevant 
ministries and atolls has commenced within 9 months of loan effectiveness;  
(vii)  ensure the commissioning of the project-related computer facilities with relevant 
ministries and atolls has been completed by 24 months of loan effectiveness; 
(viii)  ensure that MOFT has prepared for approval the financial instructions relating to 
the implementation of the amendments to the Audit Act, the public finance act 
and the public enterprise act within 1 month of their passage; 
(ix)  ensure that under the new PAS, no bank accounts containing public funds are  
opened or operated without the written consent of MOFT; 
(x)  ensure that the transfer of balances from MMA to the central ledger at MOFT will 
be subject to audit certification; and

(xi)  ensure that all purchases of foreign exchange are paid for and debited from the

B.  Conditions for Loan Effectiveness 
87.  As conditions for the effectiveness of the Loan, the Government has agreed that: 
 
(i)  the PSC will be established and equipped with the services of an administrative 
assistant, and representatives from concerned ministries and agencies will be 
appointed to the PSC; 
(ii)  a  project  director,  acceptable  to  ADB,  and  a  minimum  of  two  staff  will  be 
appointed to the PMU; 
(iii)  a financial controller or the chief accountant will be appointed to MOFT; and 
(iv)  MOFT will have submitted the draft public finance act, public enterprises act and 
the amendments to the Audit Act26 (collectively referred to as the draft laws) to 
the Law Commission, and the Law Commission will have submitted the draft 
laws (as finalized by the Law Commission), to the People’s Majlis. 
 
VI.    RECOMMENDATION 
88.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
ADB and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various currencies equivalent to 
Special Drawing Rights 3,781,000 to the Republic of the Maldives for the Strengthening of the 
Public Accounting System Project from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge 
at the rate of 1% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; a term of 
32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft Loan Agreement presented to the 
Board.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
A.  Introduction  
1.  At present no system is in place to producing annual financial statements. Substantial 
change is needed if the Government is to achieve its expected outcomes under the reform 
agenda.  The  proposed  system  is  designed  to  bring  about  improvements  in  the  levels  of 
efficiency, effectiveness, and accountability in the management of public funds and other public 
wealth. The objective of this Project is to improve the public accounting system (PAS) and 
enable the development of efficient and effective fiscal operations and macroeconomic policy. 
The Project includes: (i) setting up a new PAS based on double-entry accounting principles; and 
(ii) training of government employees involved in the various aspects of the Project.  
 
B.  Benefits 
 
1.  Gains In Efficiency 
 
2.  The  proposed  PAS  will  bring  about  fundamental  improvements  in  efficiency  and 
effectiveness to the existing accounting system of the Government. The new accounting system 
will relieve the central bank, Maldives Monetary Authority (MMA), from performing the dual role 
of a government banker and administering government accounting functions. This new system 
will enable proper segregation of functions and duties by transferring the accounting functions of 
Government to the Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT) while the banking functions remain 
with MMA. 
 
3.  The new system will also enable government ministries and departments to do away 
with a number of accounting records currently being kept in the existing system without proper 
monitoring and coordination by MOFT. Analysis of the project preparatory technical assistance 
consultants show that based on the current workload a saving of at least 27% of total staff hours 
would be achieved thereby creating an economic saving of approximately Rf9.4 million per year. 
Assuming that the government budget will grow in real terms at the same rate as in the last 5 
years or so, the savings will increase substantially. Existing staff can be redeployed in other 
areas of importance or retrained, or the staff complements could be reduced by natural attrition, 
thereby making the government operations more efficient and cost effective.  Implementation of 
the Project as part of the reform process could require additional human resources, which may 
be met in part by surplus staff from the finance sections. 
 
2.  Better and Timely Decision Making 
 
4.  The main aim of the existing system is to control the budget through the treasury general 
account maintained at MMA. More than 60% of the monthly reports that are required to be 
submitted to MOFT by the various government-spending units arrive significantly late. Such 
information is critical for good and timely decision making and required by a number of users. 
 
5.  By  2004,  a  national  computer  network  will  likely  be  established  under  an  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) financed project. This network together with the proposed PAS will 
pave way for the new PAS to be connected to the national network, enabling on-line enquiry 
and printing of various financial reports by the government-spending units. This connectivity will 
bring improvements to the timeliness and quality of decisions made.

not.  
 
9.  The establishment of the treasury division under the Project will become an effective

10.  Another major reporting deficiency of the existing PAS is the inability of the system to 
produce a set of audited financial statements of the Government.  At the end of each year, a

does not conform to international accounting standards, nor does the auditor general express 
an opinion on these financial statements of the Government. 
 
11.  The Project will specifically address these particular issues, and the proposed system

(ii) consolidated  revenue  fund;  (iii)  general  loan  fund  and  capital  works;  (iv)  trust  fund; 
(v) revolving fund; (vi) contingency fund; and (vii) other customized reports.

lead to improved credit ratings that will help the country to borrow funds in the international 
markets at much more favorable terms. Though this benefit could be substantial in the long run, 
we have not quantified the savings in the benefit-cost analysis.

E.  Overall Fiscal Impact 
 
15.  The new PAS will enable and facilitate better and greater fiscal discipline.   
 
16.  Under  the  new  system,  the  existing  1,600  bank  accounts  held  with  MMA  will  be 
consolidated  into  a  single  public  account  to  enhance  control  over  public  monies.  This 
consolidation process will bring about a significant saving in the total staff hours required for the 
day-to-day operations. The proposed financial planning division and the cash management 
section of MOFT could then play a more effective role in the management of government 
finances  by  creating  savings  through  the  opportunities  that  will  be  created  with  the 
implementation of the proposed system.   
 
17.  The flow of cash between atoll spending units and Male’ is expected to be significantly 
reduced under the new system. As estimates indicate that up to Rf30 million-40 million are at

18.  MOFT reports also indicate that approximately Rf576 million of government funds and

properly managed.  The proposed new accounting system will lead to consolidation of all such 
idle funds and pool them to get a better financial return on such deposits. 
 
19.  Utilization  of  such  deposits  in  the  cash  management  process  would  bring  about 
significant savings in net domestic interest payments by MOFT. Currently, MOFT incurs an 
average interest expense of Rf65 million per annum on loans obtained from MMA. According to

such idle funds could be invested. Assuming investment of only 25% of total idle funds at an 
interest rate of 6% (MMA lending rate) will generate an average annual return of Rf9.1 million in 
interest earnings that could be used to offset the deficit financing. 
 
20.  Furthermore lack of a commitment register is one of the biggest weaknesses in budget 
control that have resulted in overspending. As a consequence, approximately an average of 
Rf1.8 million would be incurred each year by various government units over and above the 
allocated budget. This has become a common occurrence, and is often realized only at a much 
later stage. More importantly, this disrupts the allocation of resources and hinders effective 
planning  of  economic  development  activities.  The  new  system  will  improve  the  monitoring 
mechanisms and rectify such situations in a timely manner. 
 
21.  The overall fiscal impact of the Project in the medium to long term will be clearly positive. 
Provided that the proposed components of this Project are implemented effectively along with 
good cash management, the resulting outcomes and economic benefits will by far outweigh the 
costs associated with the Project and the proposed PAS is thus expected to bring about 
substantial economic benefits to the country.
